user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_destroy(&impl->id) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CountSemDelete_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No. In the shown usage there is no violation: OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET yields a pointer to a mutable OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t in the global table (OS_impl_count_sem_table) and the caller (OS_CountSemDelete_Impl) needs a mutable record to call sem_destroy(&impl->id) which modifies the semaphore. Making the returned pointer const would prevent required modification, so Rule 8.13 (“pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible”) is not violated here. (Note: a potential violation would occur if the table and its uses were purely read-only — in that case the table elements and the macro should be const-qualified — or if the macro suppressed a const qualifier when passing a const token to a callee that expects a non-const pointer.)
